author: Mark Perigard
title: 'The Walking Dead': How long is the line to the buffet anyway? | Love That TV | Television News
text:
We need to talk about Glenn.
Sure, there are many things to discuss about the sixth season premiere of AMC's “The Walking Dead” - Did it really need to be 60 minutes with 30 minutes of commercials? – but we need to talk about the pizza delivery boy turned unlikely post-apocalyptic leader and mentor to wannabe psychos.
It's that last part I'm worried about.
At the end of last season, Alexandria resident Nicholas (Michael Traynor) lured Glenn out to the woods, battered him and left him for dead.
Glenn's response, seen in this episode, takes turning the other cheek to a crazy level.
He's teaching his would-be killer how to be a zombie slayer.
That's wonderful for Alexandria – and no doubt, for Nicholas' survival – but that quality of mercy in this brutal world usually ends up with the forgiver being eaten.
Dale, Hershel, even Andrea , were people with strong views about helping others less fortunate.
And look where it got them.
“Glenn saves people,” Maggie (Lauren Cohan) said with admiration. “He saves people like that.”
When you act like a savior, that's when this show crucifies you.
Nicholas, to give him credit, seems genuinely grateful for a second chance and willing to publicly proclaim Glenn's skill at zombie killing, as we saw when the group hit a roadblock in its great Biter Walkoff 2015.
So maybe this will turn out OK.
Yes, I am aware of the fate of Glenn in creator Robert Kirkman's comic book, and, no, I don't think the show will go that route with Glenn. It would be too predictable. More likely, some other character will meet that gruesome, memorable end.
But Glenn could still be headed for a reckoning, and I don't want that.
Who didn't know Carter (Ethan Embry) was going to die? I see no hands.
Rick (Andrew Lincoln) did both the practical thing and showed him a mercy when he killed him. A bite that tears a chunk of face – how can you manage that? As Rick predicted earlier, somebody like that, he's going to die no matter what.
On one level, Rick and Glenn both acted the same way - pardoning the men who plotted their deaths. But Glenn moves with an open heart; Rick operates from a darker place, which we saw.
One man taking it all in – Morgan.
How great is it to see Lennie James as a series regular? He disagrees with Rick's tactics and could become an opponent fighting for the soul of Alexandria.
My favorite moment of the night: When Morgan asked Carol (Melissa McBride) if she, like Rick, was a cop.
“You're always watching. You always seem ready,” he said.
“For what?”
“To handle things.”
“Aren't you sweet,” Carol responded, a perfectly Southern way of saying, “Go to hell.”
But that blaring horn – a zombie lunch siren – can only mean the residents of Alexandria are out of time.
Fight or die.
What did you think of the season premiere of "The Walking Dead"?
